results.headline: Family Nourishment

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Touch of Spice

results.summary_short: The food metaphors pile up like layers of an overstuffed sandwich in “A Touch of Spice.”

results.headline: Struggle and Rescue, a Duet in Sharps and Minors

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Soloist

results.summary_short: Some of the lost souls in “The Soloist,” a big studio movie about a one-man rescue mission, look as thin as the crack pipes clamped between their lips.

results.headline: First Preschool, Then the Ivy League

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nursery University

results.summary_short: If you thrill to the sight of a preschool teacher bringing an investment banker to his knees, then “Nursery University” is for you.

results.headline: Quiet House, Thoughtful Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Empty Nest

results.summary_short: In “Empty Nest,” a couple is forced to question their identities and relationships now that parenting is not their most immediate concern.

results.headline: Back to the ’80s, for Assorted Hookups in a Wasteland of Privilege

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Informers

results.summary_short: The main characters in “The Informers” are not so much characters as symbols of, well, of some pretty bad stuff.

results.headline: Birmingham Brawler in the Big City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fighting

results.summary_short: You might expect a movie called “Fighting” to be a blunt, literal affair, and in the case of Dito Montiel’s new film, you would not be wrong.

results.headline: Our Planet, Pole to Pole, Cold to Hot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Earth

results.summary_short: Leave it to Disney to make global warming as soothing as a full-body massage with “Earth.”

results.headline: Two Children Are Cast Adrift in a World Without Anchors

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Treeless Mountain

results.summary_short: “Treeless Mountain” has the tang of real life, though this is realism that has been filtered through 60 or so years of world art cinema.

results.headline: He Might Lack a Ticker, but He’s Still a Time Bomb

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crank: High Voltage

results.summary_short: “Crank: High Voltage,” starring Jason Statham as a man with a machine instead of a heart, is boorish, bigoted and borderline pornographic.

results.headline: A French Resistance of Another Sort

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leon Morin, Priest

results.summary_short: “Léon Morin, Priest” involves the push and pull between a Roman Catholic priest and one of his female parishioners.

results.headline: Fighting Injustice in Small-Town Texas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Violet

results.summary_short: “American Violet,” which is based on real events that took place in late 2000, has the quasi-documentary feel of a well-made television drama.

results.headline: In a Grove, a War of Wills and Words

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lemon Tree

results.summary_short: “Lemon Tree” is a wrenching, richly layered feminist allegory as well as a geopolitical one.

results.headline: Magician’s Twisting Road Comes to Bittersweet End

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Is Anybody There?

results.summary_short: Michael Caine uses his dramatic powers as an aging magician in “Is Anybody There?”

results.headline: What They Did for Work (Love, Too)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Every Little Step

results.summary_short: In “Every Little Step,” life imitates art, art reflects life, and the distinctions threaten, quite pleasantly, to blur altogether.

results.headline: Tale of an Anxious Wanderer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sleep Dealer

results.summary_short: “Sleep Dealer” is an unusually thoughtful science fiction film, using the speculative energy of the genre to explore some troubling and complex contemporary issues.

results.headline: Those Cheekbones! That Wind-Swept Hair! OMG, It’s Zac Efron!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 17 Again

results.summary_short: An adult transforms into his teen idol, er, adolescent self in “17 Again.”

results.headline: The News on Paper, and Other Artifacts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of State of Play

results.summary_short: The chance to explore the swiftly changing culture of Web-age journalism is one of several intriguing possibilities that “State of Play” squanders.

results.headline: Social and Political Transformations

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perestroika

results.summary_short: “Perestroika” is a curious combination of documentary and fiction, politics and science, sophisticated structure and incompetent drama.

results.headline: The Domestic Chaos of Retired Sea Captains

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Golden Boys

results.summary_short: “The Golden Boys” is an object lesson in how to squander a seasoned cast, a charming premise and a breathtaking location.

results.headline: In Peru, Making the Invisible Visible

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Olvido

results.summary_short: “Oblivion” is a movie so suffused with feeling for its human subjects that when a man starts weeping, you don’t feel dirty about watching his tears fall.
